description: Katok is a Nyingma monastery in Derge that focuses on the Kama tradition (orally transmitted teachings).
Associated Figures: [Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo](tm.fig.14)|[Katok](tm.mon.32)|Family member of lamas|Nyingma teachings|Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo was blessed by lamas (including his uncle) at the monastery of Katok and given a dharma name. One of his reincarnations was identified here.,"[Chokgyur Lingpa](tm.fig.17)|[Katok](tm.mon.32)|pilgrim, teacher|Barche Kunsel|Chokgyur Lingpa visited Katok with the lamas Khyentse Wangpo and Jamgon Kongtrul, and did consecrations and empowerments, and received transmissions."

name: Zha Lhakhang
description: Zha Lhakang was an imperial-era Nyingma monastery, associated with the treasure teachings of Vimalamitra. It was later converted into a Geluk temple.

name: Tanak Tubten Namgyel
description: Tanak Tubten was a Sakya monastery founded by Gorampa Sonam Sengge. It served as a teaching college

name: Gyuto Dratsang (Upper Tantric College)
description: Gyuto Dratsang was one of the two main tantric colleges of Lhasa. It was founded by Kunga Dondrup. The college later moved into the Ramoche temple complex, and continues to operate today (after a hiatus during the Cultural Revolution).

name: Karma Gon
description: Karma Gon was the first monastery of the Karmapa incarnation lineage, founded by the first Karmapa. Karma Gon also served as the seat of the Tai Situ incarnation lineages.
Associated Figures: [Chokgyur Lingpa](tm.fig.17)|[Karma Gon](tm.mon.36)|Pilgrim||Chokgyur Lingpa paid a visit to the Fourteenth Karmapa at Karma Gon and the nearby site of Okmin Karma

name: Tashilhunpo
description: Tashilhunpo was founded by the First Dalai Lama and served (and continues to serve today) as the seat of the Panchen Lama incarnation lineage. There is a lot of controversy between the present Dalai Lama and Chinese government over the Panchen Lamas
Associated Figures: [Changkya Rolpai Dorje](tm.fig.20)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||,[Gendun Drub (First Dalai Lama)](tm.fig.23)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||,"[5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe](tm.fig.29)|[Tashilhunpo](tm.mon.37)|||"

name: Tsetang
description: Tsetang was originally a Kagyu monastery affiliated with Densatil. It was later converted to the Geluk tradition under the Dalai Lamas
Associated Figures: "[Gyeltsabje Darma Rinchen](tm.fig.12)|[Tsetang](tm.mon.38)|Student|Kagyu teachings|Gyeltsabje did some of his early studies at the Kagyu monastery Tsetang, which was eventually converted to Geluk"

name: Mindroling
description: Mindroling is one of the most important Nyingma monasteries. It was founded by Terdak Lingpa with the patronage of the Fifth Dalai Lama. It continues to be led by Terdak Lingpa’s descendants
Associated Figures: "[Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo](tm.fig.14)|[Mindroling](tm.mon.39)|Ordainee, student|Terdak Lingpa, yangdak Heruka|Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo was ordained as a monk at Mindroling, and received Nyingma treasure teachings (terma) and Sakya teachings.",[Chokgyur Lingpa](tm.fig.17)|[Mindroling](tm.mon.39)|Pilgrim||Chokgyur Lingpa went on pilgrimage to Mindroling toward the end of his life

name: Reting
description: Reting was originally founded as the scholastic center of the Kadampa school. Later on, it became the home monastery of the Geluk Reting incarnation lineage, one of the lineages from which the regents of the Dalai Lama were selected.
Associated Figures: "[Rendawa Shonnu Lodro](tm.fig.16)|[Reting](tm.mon.40)|teacher|Mikstema|Rendawa Shonnu Lodro taught Tsongkhapa here, and Tsongkhapa wrote the Miktsema verses in his honor; Rendawa rededicated them to Tsongkhapa.","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Reting](tm.mon.40)|||"

name: Neten
description: Neten is a Nyingma monastery that is the seat of the Neten Chokling incarnation line.
Associated Figures: "[Chokgyur Lingpa](tm.fig.17)|[Neten](tm.mon.41)|Founder||Chokgyur Lingpa founded Neten monastery at the end of his life, and it became the seat of the Chokling incarnation lineage. He died there and his relics were kept at Neten."

name: Gonlung Jampa Ling
description: Gonlung Jampa Ling is one of the largest monasteries in Amdo. It is a seat of the Changkya and Tukwan incarnation lineages
Associated Figures: [Changkya Rolpai Dorje](tm.fig.20)|[Gonlung Jampa Ling](tm.mon.42)|||

name: Dechen Teng
description: Dechen Teng was a hermitage built by the Third Karmapa.
Associated Figures: [The First Zhamarpa Drakpa Sengge](tm.fig.21)|[Dechen Teng](tm.mon.43)|||

name: Nartang
description: Nartang was a Kadampa monastery famous for its wood block printing press (one of the early editions of the Kangyur came from here).
Associated Figures:
[Gendun Drub (First Dalai Lama)](tm.fig.23)|[Nartang](tm.mon.44)|||,"[Puntsok Pelzang
](tm.fig.30)|[Nartang](tm.mon.44)|||",[Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Nartang](tm.mon.44)|||

name: Śrī Siṃha College
description: Śrī Siṃha is a Nyingma monastic college that is part of Dzokchen monastery.

name: Nyetang Drolma Lhakang
description: Nyetang Drolma Lhakang is a Kadam monastery that houses the relics of Atisha.
Associated Figures:
"[Lama Dampa Sonam Gyeltsen
](tm.fig.27)|[Nyetang Drolma Lhakang](tm.mon.46)|||"

name: Yangpachen
description: Yangpachen was the seat of the Shamarpa incarnations for a time. It was later confiscated by the Lhasa Ganden Palace government in retaliation for the Shamarpa's alliance with Nepal in a war with Tibet (a war that involved sectarian conflict between Kagyu and the Geluk rulers of Tibet). It was converted back to Karma Kagyu in the modern era.
Associated Figures: [Go Lotsawa Shonnu Pel](tm.fig.28)|[Yangpachen](tm.mon.47)|||

name: Potala
description: The Potala was the palace of the Dalai Lamas. It was built on the site of Songtsen Gampo’s original palace. In 1959, the Dalai Lama went into exile, and the palace is currently open as a tourist attraction.
Associated Figures: "[5th Panchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe](tm.fig.29)|[Potala](tm.mon.48)|||"

name: Taklung
description: Taklung monastery is the center of the Taklung Kagyu tradition.
Associated Figures:
"[Puntsok Pelzang
](tm.fig.30)|[Taklung](tm.mon.49)|||","[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Taklung](tm.mon.49)|||"

name: Boudanath
description: Boudanath is an ancient stupa near Kathmandu, Nepal. It was often visited by Tibetan pilgrims and continues to be revered by Buddhists living in Nepal.
Associated Figures: [Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Boudanath](tm.mon.50)|||

name: Gyume Dratsang (Lower Tantric College)
description: Gyme Dratsang is one of two tantric colleges in the Geluk monastic system. It was founded by Sherab Sengge and specializes in the practices of Guhyasamaja, Akshobhya, and Vajrabhairava.

name: Pelyul
description: Pelyul is one of the mother monasteries of the Nyingma tradition. It was founded by Rigdzin Kunzang Sherab.
Associated Figures: "[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Pelyul](tm.mon.52)|||"

name: Palge Samten Ling
description: Palge Samten Ling is a Nyingma hermitage that is also the site of the Dzatrul tulku.
Associated Figures: [Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo](tm.fig.34)|[Palge Samten Ling](tm.mon.53)|||

name: Zhalu
description: Zhalu is one of the oldest continuously operating monasteries in Tibet. It was a center of Kadampa and early Sakya scholarship
Associated Figures: [Buton Rinchen Drup](tm.fig.36)|[Zhalu](tm.mon.54)|||

name: Densatil
description: Densatil is a monastery founded by Phakmodrupa, which also served as the seat of the royal Phakmodrupa dynasty that ruled much of Tibet during the 14th century.
Associated Figures: [Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Densatil](tm.mon.55)|||

name: Arik Gonchen
description: Arik Gonchen is a monastery in Amdo that was built as a memorial to the Third and Fifth Dalai Lamas.

name: Ralung
description: Ralung is a monastery important to Drukpa Kagyu. It was founded by Tsangpa Gyare and controlled by the Goa clan through the seventeenth century
Associated Figures: [Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Ralung](tm.mon.57)|||

name: Dobi Ganden Pelgye Ling
description: Dobi Ganden Pelgye Ling was a monastic college in Amdo associated with Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol. It was converted to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century.
Associated Figures: [Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Dobi Ganden Pelgye Ling](tm.mon.58)|||

name: Segyu Dratsang
description: Segyu Dratsang was the first Geluk monastery dedicated to tantric practice. It was founded by Sherab Sengge and Pelden Zangpo.

name: Daklha Gampo
description: Dalkha Gampo temple was founded by Gampopa and continued to be headed by his family and his successive incarnations. The temple is believed to be blessed by Songtsen Gampo.
Associated Figures: "[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Daklha Gampo](tm.mon.60)|||"

name: Dzagyel
description: Dzagyel was a Nyingma monastery founded by the First Dodrupchen. One of its most famous residents was Patrul Rinpoche.
Associated Figures: [Patrul Orgyen Jigme Chokyi Wangpo](tm.fig.34)|[Dzagyel](tm.mon.61)|||

name: Bodong E
description: Bodong E was a monastery that was central to the Bodong tradition and residence of Bodong Panchen Choke Namgyel.
Associated Figures: [Orgyan Tendzin Norbu](tm.fig.25)|[Bodong E](tm.mon.62)|||

name: Purbuchok
description: Purbuchok is a hermitage built above Sera monastery. It is believed to be Padmasambhava’s cave. The hermitage was originally part of the Tselpa Kagyu tradition and converted to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century

name: Wolkha Cholung
description: Wolkha Cholung hermitage was founded by Tsongkhapa. It contains an image of Tsongkhapa and his footprints.

name: Lhundrubteng
description: Lhundrubteng (sometimes called Gonchen) is a Sakya monastery in Derge with close ties to Ngor Monastery. It includes the Derge Printing House.

name: Dodrupchen
description: Dodrupchen is a monastery founded by the First Dodrupchen Jigme Trinle Ozer. It was originally the site of a tent camp monastery.

name: Jang Tana
description: Jang Tana is a Yelpa Kagyu monastery founded by Yelpa Yeshe Tse. It is currently a branch monastery of Tsurphu. Jang Tana houses relics of Gesar of Ling, the legendary Tibetan epic hero.

name: Drakram
description: Drakram is a Jonang monastery in Tsang, where Chokla Namgyel studied.

name: Labrang Tashikhyil
description: Labrang Tashikhyil is a very large Geluk monastery in Amdo. It is the seat of the Jamyang Zhepa incarnation lineage. Labrang has six colleges including a debate college, a medical college, and several tantric colleges.

name: Serdokchen
description: Serdokchen is a Sakya monastery near Shigatse which was founded by Panchen Donyo Pel. He passed it on to his disciple Panchen Shakya Chokde.

name: Amdo Chubzang
description: Amdo Chubzang is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was rebuilt several times. At one time it was the wealthiest monastery in the Tsongkha region.

name: Bangri Jokpo
description: Bangri Jokpo is a Nyingma monastic community in Kong, founded by Jetsun Nyingpo.

name: Chamdo Jampa Ling
Associated Figures: "[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Chamdo Jampa Ling](tm.mon.75)|||"

name: Kailash
description: A sacred mountain
Associated Figures: [Orgyan Tendzin Norbu](tm.fig.25)|[Kailash](tm.mon.79)|||,[Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol](tm.fig.31)|[Kailash](tm.mon.79)|||

name: Pelkhor Chode
Associated Figures: [Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Pelkhor Chode](tm.mon.81)|||

name: Drak Yongdzong
Associated Figures: "[The First Dzogchen Drubwang, Pema Rigdzin](tm.fig.33)|[Drak Yongdzong](tm.mon.90)|||"

name: Lhasa Tsuklakhang
Associated Figures: [Vanaratna](tm.fig.37)|[Lhasa Tsuklakhang](tm.mon.94)|||
